body:
> #### Proposed
> There will be a single functional interface that all soft assertions classes must implement. This has **one default method** that is used to generate the proxy classes. Then subinterfaces of this interface can call this method in their `default assertThat()` implementations. Because the soft assertion entry points can be interfaces, you can combine several of them into a single class.

Sorry, that should have read "one abstract method" or "one non-default method", not "one default method". Apologies for any confusion.
We'll look into it soon, promise!

@kriegfrj sorry for the late feedback, I totally agree having one single entry point for all soft assertions would be great!

One challenge I'm not sure is addressed by the proposed  approach is to collect assertion errors from all different soft assertions types into one place, at the moment that place is the SoftProxies.errorCollector instance built when soft assertions are created). 

Said otherwise if you have 2 errors from `Project1SoftAssertions` and one from `Project2SoftAssertions`, how do make sure the 3 errors with one call to `assertAll()`? 

Either `assertAll()` called in the test is aware of all implemented soft assertions and is able to get all errors for each of them (I'm not sure this technically feasible) or the `SoftProxies.errorCollector` instance is shared between all soft assertions instances (but again, not sure it is possible).

I think the way to go is to create a spike and see if we can make it work.

> @kriegfrj sorry for the late feedback, I totally agree having one single entry point for all soft assertions would be great!
>

No problems @joel-costigliola !

> One challenge I'm not sure is addressed by the proposed approach is to collect assertion errors from all different soft assertions types into one place, at the moment that place is the SoftProxies.errorCollector instance built when soft assertions are created).
> 
> Said otherwise if you have 2 errors from `Project1SoftAssertions` and one from `Project2SoftAssertions`, how do make sure the 3 errors with one call to `assertAll()`?
> 
> Either `assertAll()` called in the test is aware of all implemented soft assertions and is able to get all errors for each of them (I'm not sure this technically feasible) or the `SoftProxies.errorCollector` instance is shared between all soft assertions instances (but again, not sure it is possible).
> 

I think the way I put it together takes care of that, because there is only one concrete implementation of the `proxy()` method (belonging to `AbstractSoftAssertions`), which points all of the generated assertion classes to the same `SoftProxies.errorCollector` instance. This must be the case, because only classes can actually have concrete instances, so the n `SoftAssertion` interfaces can't have their own error collector instances.

The only disadvantage of this is that `proxy()` must become a public method.

> I think the way to go is to create a spike and see if we can make it work.

:+1: If I get some time I'll give it a try; otherwise feel free!
I just realised that `proxy()` is already a public method, so no problems there!

issue.title: Restructure to allow combining soft assertions entry points

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Changes soft assertions entry point implementations to be interfaces with default methods, rather than classes. This allows you to combine multiple of them into a single entry point class.

#### Check List:
* Fixes #1569
* Unit tests : YES
* Javadoc with a code example (on API only) : Not yet (will add if core team is happy with the implementation)

body: Hi @joel-costigliola , I've just submitted a "spike" as a PR (#1817). There is an example test case which illustrates combining two soft assertion entry points into one (`org.assertj.core.api.abstract_.SoftAssertionsMultipleProjectsTest`). Have a look and see if you like it (or not...). :smile:
